page.title: 17The Doll Museum at Cromwell
page.content: {Vina Cooke}runs the{Museum of Dolls and{Bygone Childhood}at the Old Rectory in{Cromwell.}The{Rectory}dates from about{1685}and has housed the museum since 1984 giving a new lease of life to this fine building which had been near empty for many years. She first made dolls as a little girl during World War 2 when dolls were scarce. Her first doll was{Snow {White,}modelled in candle wax. She began making dolls for her small daughter and developed a technique using stretchy{stockinette}which over the years has become her unique style. Soon she was creating her own gallery of portrait dolls of Film Stars and Pop Stars. A gallery of dolls of Kings and Queens followed. With her husband she now also makes{porcelain}dolls with wooden, jointed bodies which are sent to customers all over the world.
